image.caption: Painless ... aspirin has been hailed as a treatment for depression, dementia and even cancer

article.caption: Go brain training
Working without machines
Denise Van Outen: Cycling makes me feel like a kid again

articles.articlebody:
DEPRESSION, heart disease, dementia and now cancer could all be prevented by taking aspirin.

It costs just 1p a tablet, but Oxford scientists said this week that taking an aspirin a day can reduce your risk of cancer.

A study found the pills not only reduce the chances of contracting the illness, but also protect against it spreading.

Experts believe the evidence is so strong that, in future, the NHS watchdog NICE may issue guidelines advising doctors to prescribe it to cancer sufferers.

The research, involving 200,000 patients, found that aspirin can cut the risk of dying of cancer by 37 per cent if taken every day for five years. Aspirin works by suppressing the creation of prostaglandin, a hormone that carries information about pain to the brain. It was first sold as 1899 as a powder by the German firm Bayer.

Aspirin can clearly do more than banish headaches, though some experts believe it could do more harm than good.

Here, we look at some of the surprising uses.

Depression

SOME experts believe depression and inflammation could be linked after small studies found some depressed people have high levels of cytokines  naturally occurring chemicals with inflammatory properties  in the body.

So because it's an anti-inflammatory drug, aspirin might be able to help.

One study followed 386 women for ten years  22 developed depression after the age of 50.

Of these only one had taken aspirin.

But among those who did not develop depression, almost a third were taking it.

Acne

A KEY ingredient in aspirin is salicylic acid, which is used in many of today's off-the-shelf acne products.

Mix a tablet with water then rub the solution on to your skin.

Leave it on for two minutes, then rinse off.

This will dry your pimples out and your spots will go faster.

If you have normal or dry skin don't try this more than once a week as you will lose too much moisture from your skin.

Dandruff

A COMMON cause of this is a tiny yeast called Pityroporum ovale, which lives on the scalp. Aspirin is a mild anti-fungal so it can help.

Crush two tablets and mix them with one serving of shampoo.

Apply the mixture to your hair and leave for about two minutes so it can settle on your scalp.

Rinse it off and shampoo your hair again.

Dementia

STUDIES have found that Alzheimer's disease, the most common form of dementia, is an inflammatory condition of the brain so aspirin might be effective in treating it.

Research carried out in Utah, involving the observation and testing of more than 3,000 people, suggested taking it could reduce the risk of contracting the condition by 23 per cent.

Heart disease

IT IS thought it can help by reducing inflammation in the arteries that supply the heart  making the blood less likely to become sticky and form a deadly clot.

In some studies, taking aspirin reduced the likelihood of a cardiovascular problem, including heart disease, heart attack or stroke, by as much as 44 per cent.

Experts also found it can help someone who has already had a heart attack or a stroke by reducing the risk of having another by a third.

Athlete's Foot

ATHLETE'S foot and other fungal infections can be treated using a few aspirin pills and talcum powder.

Grind three pills until they are in a powder form.

Then mix the powdered aspirin with some talcum powder.

Apply the mixture on to the infected area of skin.

Do this process twice a day to kill the fungi and to treat the irritation.

In-growing hair

HAVE you got a painful in-growing hair that won't budge?

Aspirin is made up of acetylsalicylic acid, which exfoliates skin and has anti-inflammatory properties.

So applying a thick paste made of crushed aspirin and a little warm water could help you remove it with ease.

Apply it to the hair and leave to settle for ten to 15 minutes. Then remove using warm water.

This should get rid of the hair, or at least make it easier to remove.

Pre-eclampsia

A DAILY dose of aspirin during pregnancy could cut the risk of pre-eclampsia, a condition that threatens the lives of both mother and baby.

A study of 32,000 women published in The Lancet medical journal found that mums who took it were ten per cent less likely to develop the condition.

Insect bites

AS these are marked by redness, itchiness and sometimes a burning sensation, aspirin  an anti-inflammatory  can help clear these up.

Wet the affected area and rub a small aspirin over the skin to help relieve the pain caused by mosquito bites or stings from a bee, wasp or hornet.

Taking it orally could also help to reduce any painful swelling.

Shingles

ASPIRIN is thought to be one of the most effective treatments for dealing with the pain and uncomfortable symptoms associated with shingles.

Mash two tablets into a paste and use a clean cotton swab to apply it to the skin.

The risks...

  • ONE in five asthmatics are at risk of a severe reaction to aspirin, according to research in Australia and the UK.

  • A recent London University study linked taking aspirin with a 30 per cent rise in the risk of debilitating  and potentially fatal  internal bleeding.

  • A study last January advised doctors to stop prescribing aspirin to ward off heart attacks as it raises the risk of bleeding in the stomach by a third.

  • Oxford researchers say a daily dose as small as 75mg could increase the risk of abdominal bleeding.

  • Anyone with an allergy to aspirin or a bleeding or clotting disorder should not use it for any purpose.

    If in doubt, consult your GP.
articles.teaser: MANY illnesses and now even CANCER could apparently be prevented by taking aspirin
articles.headline: Aspirin's not just for headaches
articles.subdeck: Painless ... aspirin has been hailed as a treatment for depression, dementia and even cancer

image.caption: 'Cameron fills my life with love and joy' ... Crystal and her 7-year-old son

article.caption: Lover offered me £2,000 to abort our Down's boy... but look how full of life he is now!
Susan Boyle: I can take whatever Ricky Gervais says... he's the one with the problem not me
Twit Joey calls rival a 'mong'
My Down's girl almost died, now she's a model

articles.articlebody:
CRYSTAL Pawson cradled her newborn son and feared, at 16, she was too young to be the mum he needed.

Less than 20 minutes later her worries were magnified when doctors revealed her baby had Down's syndrome.

It was a bombshell blow  but 11 years on Crystal believes she is Britain's luckiest mum.

She said: "Cameron is loyal, funny and affectionate and fills my life with love and joy.

"You couldn't hope to meet a more smashing lad. Having Cameron has been the making of me."

The lad is also a brilliant big brother to Luke, ten, Jake, four, Mackenzie, two, and four-month-old Brooklyn.

As the Down's Syndrome Association runs its awareness campaign this week, courageous Crystal, 27, revealed how Cameron has made her a better person.

Around one in every 1,000 babies born in the UK will have Down's and there are 60,000 people in the UK with the condition.

Although the chance of a baby having Down's is higher for older mothers, more babies with Down's are born to younger women  because they have more children.

Crystal fell pregnant at 15 and as the likelihood of having a Down's baby was considered so rare for a mum-to-be of her age, doctors had not even asked if she wanted to be tested.

Like many women, Crystal assumed only older mums had Down's children. She admits when she was first told of her son's diagnosis at Harrogate District Hospital in North Yorkshire, she was horrified and ashamed.

She said: "I was still getting my head round the fact he had Down's when three hours after his birth he was whisked off for a scan.

"When they brought my baby back and told me he had three holes in his heart and would need a major op to fix it, I just fell apart."

The devastated teenager sobbed in her mother's arms.

Back at home in Wetherby, West Yorks, sharing a room with her sister and her new tot made life even harder.

She says: "I couldn't bear to go out, not because I didn't want to show him off but I was so scared he would die.

"He seemed so vulnerable and I was way out of my depth. I sobbed myself to sleep every night and kept thinking 'why me?'"

Cameron's dad, 16-year-old Drew, stood by her  visiting the pair regularly. But Crystal was convinced he would leave her.

She said: "All his mates were out clubbing and he was a 16-year-old lad with a baby with Down's."

At three months old Cameron went in for the op to fix the holes in his heart.

Crystal was warned he would be in hospital for up to three months but after just three weeks he was doing so well he was discharged.

Back at home, while most girls her age were out having fun, 16-year-old Crystal was caring for a very sick baby. Then something amazing happened.

Crystal said: "Cameron just fought and fought and suddenly I realised it was time to stop feeling sorry for myself. I gave myself a massive boot up the backside.

"OK, my son wasn't the perfect baby but he was my son and he deserved a mum who would fight for him all the way."

Drew and Crystal moved in together and the teen parents learnt Makaton, a language programme using signs and symbols, so they could communicate with Cameron as he grew up.

Crystal said: "Being able to sign was a major bonus.

"Cameron and I formed a remarkable bond and suddenly I realised his disability was anything but."

When Crystal fell pregnant with another child when Cameron was just 18 months old, a few friends said she wouldn't be able to cope.

She was offered a nuchal scan to determine the likelihood of Down's, but turned it down.

She said: "I didn't want to know. I coped with Cameron and I knew I'd cope again."

Baby Luke was born healthy, as was Jake two years after.

Crystal said: "The specialists don't know why I had a baby with Down's so young and then it never occurred again. They say it's extremely rare."

When Cameron was seven, Crystal split from his dad, suddenly finding herself a single mum to three boys.

She said: "I'm not saying it was easy but dealing with Cameron gave me the strength to deal with anything.

"Some people close to me thought I would have a breakdown but it was actually Cameron that kept me going.

"He developed this really cheeky, funny personality. He had me in stitches and when I was down he seemed to sense it and would give me a cuddle. He's just so happy I couldn't be sad around him."

Crystal has since found love with 21-year-old shop worker Darren Hooper. The couple have two sons.

She said: "Life's good. Cameron goes to a special needs school which he loves and has really boosted his speech and learning.

"I'll admit that when I first heard my little boy had Down's I reached the depths of despair but now I don't see him as a boy with problems.

"I see him for what he is  an unbelievably loving little boy who loves cuddles and has tons of affection and love to give.

"I know people thought I didn't have the maturity to cope but having Cameron has been the making of me."

And Crystal has high hopes for Cameron's future: "I would love him to move out of home, get a job, marry and go on to have his own family one day and there's no reason why he can't achieve any of those dreams.

"Cameron has ambitions like any boys his age. He loves playing sports and listening to Lady GaGa.

"He tells me he wants to be a footballer one day and I tell him he should aim high and go for it.

"Every child, no matter if they have Down's syndrome, should be given a chance to prove what they can do and lead as ordinary a life as possible."

Sarah offers other parents hope



DOWN'S syndrome actress Sarah Gordy is proof that people with disabilities can lead a full and rewarding life.

The 34-year-old  who plays Lady Pamela on BBC drama Upstairs Downstairs  has starred in many TV shows and plays. And her mum Jane, 63, could not be more proud of her daughter.

But Jane, speaking about discovering her first-born had Down's syndrome, admitted: "Being completely honest, if I was given a test and told my baby had Down's I would have considered a termination.

"I'd have been terrified about not being able to look after her. But that saddens me now.

"When I fell pregnant I wasn't ready to be a mum. In my 20s at the time, I'd never changed a nappy so I felt very unprepared.

"When Sarah was born I couldn't believe how beautiful she was."

Jane didn't have any tests for Down's syndrome because she was under 28 when she fell pregnant. But the paediatrician noticed Sarah had the condition from the moment he saw her.

Jane said: "Calling my husband Jerry aside, he told him that Sarah had the condition. Not only that, but he asked him not to tell me.

"He said it was important for me to form a bond with Sarah first.

"Looking back I don't know how poor Jerry kept it to himself."

It wasn't until four days later that Jane found out.

She said: "I was heartbroken and terrified I would lose my baby. He kept telling me about potential heart problems and operations she'd need.

"But finding out turned me from a girl into a fully-fledged mother."

Luckily, Sarah didn't need any operations. Jane said: "I wish I knew back then what I know now, about how much of an amazing life she'd have."

Jane had another daughter, Catherine, now 32, 16 months after Sarah and admits she felt relief when tests showed she did not have Down's.

Jane said: "I just didn't know if having two children with the condition would be too much.

"I wish parents-to-be were provided with more information about Down's syndrome before they make a decision about termination.

"No one should ever feel pressured either way, but it's such a difficult decision to make without knowing exactly what it will entail."

While everything took longer with Sarah, Jane says she soon realised her daughter had an incredible ability to feel what other people feel.

She said: "If I'm ever stressed or worried and I tell Sarah I'm fine she will say, 'No you're not,' and I have to come clean. We're very close as no emotion goes unnoticed."

And Jane explains that Down's syndrome actors work very differently to those without the condition.

She said: "The interesting thing about Sarah is she doesn't really act. She feels very emotional on set.

"She can't fake emotion, so instead she believes everything about her character.

"Once she was acting as an abused wife and I saw how much the abusive words were hurting her.

"When she came off set I said, 'Sarah  you're a beautiful, successful actress' and she slowly remembered that.

"I like to think that Sarah being successful on TV gives parents who are expecting a Down's syndrome child strength and confidence that their child can lead a really healthy life."

myView



By CAROL BOYS, Chief Executive at Down's Syndrome Association

WE have seen great improvements in the lives of people with Down's syndrome since the association's formation in 1970.

Today, the average life expectancy of people with Down's syndrome is 60 to 65 years, compared to 35 to 40 back in 1970. They are now legally entitled to quality healthcare, good education and jobs and live fulfilling lives.

People with Down's all have a degree of learning difficulty but with the right support they are able to reach many milestones that other people reach.

See downs-syndrome.org.uk or call 0208 614 5100.
articles.byline: By KATE THOMPSON and JENNY FRANCIS
articles.teaser: DIAGNOSIS was a bombshell for Crystal. Now she believes she is Britain's luckiest mum
articles.headline: Mum inspired by Down's son
articles.subdeck: 'Cameron fills my life with love and joy' ... Crystal and her 7-year-old son

article.caption: Sunder the influence...

articles.articlebody:
MEMORY loss, weight gain and depression can all be symptoms of regular heavy nights out drinking.

Many celebrities, including Fearne Cotton, Leona Lewis and Jessie J, are choosing to ditch alcohol.

Prince Harry has stopped pubbing to concentrate on his helicopter training.

Increasing numbers of people are binning the booze and banishing binge drinking from their lives to seek out a healthier lifestyle.

According to NHS figures, at least one in six adults has sworn off alcohol completely, shunning peer pressure in favour of a hangover-free life.

JENNY FRANCIS meets five women who have gone teetotal to find out what life is like without booze.

Linda Obena, 28



THE digital producer from Crystal Palace in south east London went teetotal in October. Sick of her unhealthy lifestyle and size 18 waist, Linda decided to ditch booze for good. She says:

Last autumn I was stuck in a destructive routine of drinking and eating too much.

I'd just broken up with my boyfriend and wanted to move on. I'd read about the LighterLife diet and wanted to give it a go.

Overnight I gave up alcohol and started eating four food packs a day, containing 5-600 calories.

It was a complete shock to the system and the first week was really hard, but I knew it would be worth it.

I used to drink a bottle of wine most nights, on Fridays I'd have work drinks and Saturdays I'd be out drinking with non-work friends.

Sundays were spent recovering. It was relentless. Drinking with clients and colleagues was part of my life and I'd got myself into really bad habits.

It was only after I gave it up I noticed what a big impact it had.

Now after a work night out I'll come into the office whistling and full of energy, while my colleagues are often a step behind me. And I remember all the office gossip!

It's been five months now and I feel stronger, more confident and I have more energy than ever before.

I've gone from 14st 9lb to 12st, from a size 18-16 to a size 14-12  and I know I look as good as I feel.

Laura Coventry, 33



WEDDING photographer Laura, from Glasgow, went teetotal two years ago after bingeing on boozy nights out left her with huge memory blanks. She says:

Like most girls in their twenties and thirties I lived for the weekend.

The prospect of partying and heavy drinking got me through the working week and I'd wish away Monday to Friday.

I drank a lot, not just a couple of glasses of wine, but enough to get seriously drunk. I just loved the euphoria and the buzz that it gave me.

I'd suffer terrible hangovers, I'd regularly be in bed until 5pm with headaches and feeling sick, but I saw it as a price worth paying to let my inhibitions go.

On occasions I'd been out with friends, woken up with a shocking hangover  and realised there were huge blanks in my night out I couldn't remember.

It really scared me and for the first time I questioned why I was doing this to myself. I knew I had to change.

The first two weeks were the hardest, but I managed the first three-month goal I set myself, then extended that to six months.

Now not one drop of booze has passed my lips since February 2010.

Some friends want me to start going out drinking with them again and say that I've proven my point, but I'm determined not to drink again.

I have a fantastic new boyfriend now and I wake up on Mondays smiling, something which never happened before.

I still party but I don't need alcohol to get a buzz. Life feels so much fuller and better.

Lucy Troughton, 31



IT was last October when Lucy went teetotal after realising the damaging effect alcohol was having on her mood. The waitress, from Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, says:

I lived in London between the ages of 19 to 22 and I was out drinking socially most nights. But when I fell pregnant at 23 I didn't drink for the best part of a year.

It's not that I missed it but I still felt very young to be stuck at home, not out partying like I used to.

I was in a band so drinking was almost expected of me.

Most of my friends didn't have kids so there was always someone around to go out drinking with. I soon reverted back to weekend drinking.

I got stuck in a rut of Mondays being a write-off, like I was waiting for the day to finish the moment I woke up.

I wanted to be on form for my daughter Grace, now seven, but I was tired and only realised when it was too late that I was becoming depressed.

In mid-October last year I decided enough was enough and gave up alcohol completely.

It was, and still is, very hard. I didn't go out and became a bit of a recluse, focusing more on my music, gardening and reading.

It's had a huge effect and I really love the mornings now.

I feel so clear-headed. And people often comment on how I'm 'glowing' now.

The idea of a glass of wine with a meal is still a temptation but it does get easier to say "No".

Going teetotal has taught me what I really value. And I'm happier than ever.

Katie Carr, 22



BARMAID Katie from Bridlington, East Yorks, was a beer-swilling, pizza-scoffing ladette.

She went teetotal in July 2010 after binge drinking caused her to have a seizure and a new love interest persuaded her to transform her life. Katie says:

Tequila, sambuca, Jägerbombs  I wasn't fussy. I could get through 20 pints of lager in a night.

In June 2010, I'd been fired from my job as a waitress for consistently turning up to work reeking of alcohol.

Three weeks later, I'd spent £1,200 in my local pub. I put on nine stone in a year on a diet of booze and pizza, weighed 18.5st and was a size 22. I didn't wear make-up or dress girly.

One night in July, I was out with friends when I had a seizure in a nightclub.

I was carried out by a bouncer and taken to hospital by ambulance. The doctor instructed me to stop drinking for six weeks while they ran tests.

While I was sober, I had time to re-evaluate who I was.

Wanting to seize the day, I contacted the bouncer and asked him, "When are you going to take me out?". I was amazed when he said later that week.

Luckily, the CT scans came back clear  I'd just drunk too much. I've not been back on the booze since and have now lost eight stone.

Going teetotal is one of the best things I've ever done.

I've gone from ladette to lady.

Rebecca Spencer, 35



THE charity worker from Southend, Essex, went teetotal seven years ago after a charity trip shocked her into a lifestyle change. She says:

In 2003 I moved to London from Newcastle in search of a new job.

I had a big group of friends and we used to go out every weekend and always drank a lot of vodka. It was just something we did and I didn't see it as a problem.

In 2005 I embarked on a charity trip with Help The Aged to India to photograph how people were rebuilding their lives after the 2004 tsunami.

It was the most eye-opening, inspiring and horrendous experience, all at the same time.

The destruction was overpowering and having an alcoholic drink in that context seemed completely ridiculous.

The experience changed my values and made me completely reassess myself.

Just a few days after being in India I was in Covent Garden surrounded by young professionals knocking back drinks without a thought.

I'd seen people with absolutely nothing and I decided to re-focus my life on the things that counted. Alcohol seemed such a self-destructive extravagance.

As soon as I gave up I realised I'd never even really liked the taste of alcohol  it was just the social side of it I enjoyed.

Nine months after the charity trip I fell pregnant and later had my son.

I felt great and no part of me wanted to drink again.

I've been teetotal for seven years now and feel healthier, more energetic and have much more in my pocket  why go back?
articles.teaser: INCREASING numbers of people are binning alcohol  here five women reveal what it's like to live without booze
articles.headline: Why we're all tee totally happy
articles.subdeck: On the wagon ... (left to right) Linda, Laura, Lucy, Katie and Rebecca

image.caption: Shine on ... glossy skin is season's must-have

article.caption: Jennifer Aniston's £90k beauty bill
Go brain training
Bargain nappy rash cream hits the spots
Wacky gadgets claim to help women shun cosmetic surgery
Bow to force of the brow

articles.articlebody:
THIS is the season to embrace dewy skin. Forget heavy tans, thick layers of foundation and cakey bronzer  radiance is now the key word in the beauty world.

Catwalk models have all been given little else but radiant, glowing skin, while celebrities such as Natalie Portman are setting the precedent for softer, fresher looks.

If YOU fancy brightening your complexion, a few simple tricks can lift your skin.

LAUREN NAYLOR shares her skin secrets so you can get up and glow.

Skin perfection



LET'S face it, we'd all love to feel confident make-up free and be blessed with a radiant, glowy complexion.

But daily exposure to harsh elements can make it difficult to pull off. Look out for nourishing and calming skincare ingredients to give your skin radiance and combat dryness and redness.

Head therapist Sherelle at celebrity skin care spa Linda Meredith, whose clients include Kate Beckinsale and Gwyneth Paltrow, says: "Start by using a cleanser packed full of naturally occurring vitamins, omega oils and amino acids.

"We are exposed to various chemicals throughout our day so look for paraben-free formulas.

"Take a generous amount of cleansing product mixed with warm water and with a feather-soft touch gently massage the product in with your fingertips.

"By massaging softly you are pushing the product into your skin rather than moving facial muscles about aggressively.

And the warm water heats the skin for the products to penetrate deeper. When you rinse, use a soft sponge, gentle cotton wool pads or your hands  flannels are too abrasive.

"An old-school, tried-and-tested method that we use is to give your skin a deep steam once a week over the basin. This will help open up and deep-clean any clogged pores.

"There is nothing wrong with squeezing out blackheads  just make sure you take a thick piece of tissue and use the sides of your fingertips to push them out.

"Only do this for three to five minutes max. If they won't come, they're not ready, and if you use your fingernails you will break and damage your skin."

We love REN Hydra-Calm Cleansing Milk with peroxidase enzymes from fennel seed extract to protect distressed skin and Omega 3 and 7 essential fatty acids to reduce inflammation, £18.

Linda Meredith Paraben-free Cream Cleanser with avocado and citrus fruit oils, £39 (stockists, 020 7225 2755). Team with a brightening moisturiser such as Simple Radiance Brightening Moisturiser, £6.99 (Boots).

Pep up



IF your complexion is looking lacklustre, it's likely you need to exfoliate sluggish skin cells. Look for natural ingredients that gently slough off dead skin.

Walnut shell, papaya and pineapple are all fantastic natural exfoliators. Try Origins Never A Dull Moment skin-brightening polisher with fruit extracts to help reveal a healthy glow, £24 (Origins).

Put your feet up and slather on Elemis Papaya Enzyme Peel, £28.60 (Elemis counters). We love the intoxicating Victoria sponge-like scent.

Make me up



SKIN highlighters add radiance in an instant. You can layer under make-up or wear stand-alone.

If you are going out and want to appear more made up, try adding highlighter along the cheekbones, down the bridge of the nose and on the forehead  this gives a shimmering dewiness.

You can also place highlighter on the brow bone and under the arch of the brow to make your eyes appear brighter.

L'Oreal Lumi Magique Concealer, £8.49, (Boots) will help to brighten the eyes if you dab a small amount in the darkest areas, ie, underneath, and Bobbi Brown Creamy Concealer in Chestnut, £17, is great for darker skins. Gorgeously rich and luxurious, MAC's Strobe Cream is used by many of the world's high-profile make-up artists.

Wear it under or over make-up for a dewy, almost wet-look effect and team with MAC's Lustre Drops in Sun Rush, £17.50, for a pop of warmth.

Last but not least, finish your face with a burst of brightening blusher on the apples of your cheeks such as Gosh Natural Blush in Electric Pink, Max Factor Miracle Touch Creamy Blush in Soft Pink, £6.99, or Maybelline NY Dream Soft Blush in Peach 02, £4.49 (all Superdrug).
articles.teaser: FORGET heavy tans and thick layers of foundation  radiance is the key word on the catwalk
articles.headline: Go with the glow
articles.subdeck: Shine on ... glossy skin is season's must-have

image.caption: 'Men should wear the trousers' ... Martin Daubney

article.caption: Girl power-steering
Are women better at parking than men?

articles.articlebody:
SO a new survey tells us the depressing news that two thirds of British men let their women dress them for work.

Or, to put it another way: Only a third of men actually wear the trousers any more.

I wonder if these women spit on a hanky and scrub away a stray fleck of Weetabix from their fellas' mouths.

Because these treacherous blokes are still allowing themselves to be mothered to death  and letting down the rest of mankind.

It's blatantly not in a woman's best interests to make a man look as sharp or hot as he can. No sane man would dress his missus in heels, stockings and a minidress before packing her out the door unattended, would he?

So these men will be draped in nice, safe  even slightly offensive  clobber.

The most confident and attractive men in history dress for women, and never get dressed by them. Take this to its sexless extreme and you get those weird couples that dress identically.

From behind, it's impossible to see who's wearing the trousers.

Even celebrities who dress the same look daft. Take Posh when she cajoled Becks into sporting a matching head-to-toe leather ensemble.

I lost all respect for an old friend of mine when he turned up to the office in Crocs. He said: "The missus got them two for one in Lidl." He was chastised by all, especially the ladies present. A part of Chris died that day and we never looked at him the same again.

By allowing his missus to dress him up, he quite rightly earned the ultimate dressing down.
articles.byline: By MARTIN DAUBNEY, Former Editor of lads’ mag Loaded
articles.teaser: AS two thirds of men admit to being dressed by their partner, former Loaded Ed on why they're letting mankind down
articles.headline: Dress for women (not by them)
articles.subdeck: 'Men should wear the trousers' ... Martin Daubney

image.caption: Stay fit and quit ... tips to giving up cigarettes while keeping trim

article.caption: Ten tips to help you quit smoking
I lost my unborn baby due to smoking... Stacey, please don't do the same

articles.articlebody:
SHOCKING pictures of Stacey Solomon smoking while seven months pregnant horrified the nation.

The 22-year-old X Factor star says she has tried to kick the habit but the fags keep getting the better of her.

Weight gain is fairly common among ex-smokers and is a major reason why some women don't give up.

Here, nutritionist AMANDA URSELL and fitness expert NICKI WATERMAN tell you how to avoid piling on the pounds after you've stubbed out that final ciggie.



Diet tips



AMANDA SAYS: "Giving up smoking can lead to the pounds, if not stones, piling on.

"This is partly because nicotine seems to bump up the metabolism by about seven per cent. It appears to have a pretty instant effect that lasts for about 30 minutes per cigarette.

"The stronger the nicotine content, the greater this metabolism-boosting effect.

"Smoking also seems to help to suppress the appetite. It does this in part by helping to block the action of chemicals in the brain that stimulate hunger.

"But it is important to put things into perspective and to appreciate that, although some people do put on a lot of weight after quitting cigarettes, the average gain is between three and ten pounds.

"The good news is that some experts report that using nicotine patches helps to lower appetite, and that those who use them while trying to quit gain less weight than those who do not. Having regular 'doses' of carbohydrate may also help to beat the hunger pangs which may be triggered by quitting.

"And on the day you decide to give up, make sure you have breakfast and keep up this habit.

"Not having anything to eat first thing can be a real problem because, by mid-morning, your body will not only be craving its usual nicotine fix but will also have low blood sugar.

"It is important when giving up smoking to remember that, even though cigarettes appear to help a bit in the battle of the bulge, there are plenty of slim people who do not smoke and plenty of overweight people who do smoke.

"Continuing to smoke because you think giving up will make you fat is no excuse not to try quitting.

"Doing so could well save your life."



5 point weight proof plan



1. Don't give up when you are tired. Being tired always makes you more hungry.

2. Throw out fattening foods that might tempt you. If you can't do this, put them in a cupboard away from day-to-day foods so you are not constantly seeing them.

3. Stock up on healthy snacks such as satsumas, grapes, low-fat yogurts, small 30g servings of nuts like almonds, cashews and peanuts and some miniature dark-chocolate Green & Black's bars that you can nibble on when the nicotine withdrawal triggers hunger pangs.

4. Drink at least six to eight cups or mugs of fluids each day to help keep hydrated. Being dehydrated can make you stressed and grumpy. It is not a good idea to try to quit caffeine-containing drinks at the same time as giving up cigarettes.

5. Eat breakfast, lunch and dinner and have a small snack in between to ensure that levels of sugar in your blood are steady and stable.

Eggs on toast, cereal or fruit salad and yogurt make good breakfasts.

Tuna, chicken or hummus-stuffed pitta or wraps are examples of energy-extending lunches and spaghetti Bolognese, baked potato with baked-bean toppings, stir fries and omelettes make good dinners.



How exercise can help



NICKI SAYS: "A new study has discovered that vigorous exercise can have a positive impact on the success rate of women trying to give up smoking.

"This is exciting news, especially when combined with previous research that shows exercising for one to two hours a week while quitting also significantly reduces the amount of weight gained.

"By incorporating exercise into your quitting programme, the feelgood endorphins your body produces also help you to overcome the mood swings that come with quitting."



Tips to give up smoking



Commit to daily exercise sessions during the first month of quitting. Preferably in the morning to perk your mood up for the day ahead.

Sign up to classes, if you can, to keep you on track and schedule in things like swimming and cycling. If you prefer, a fast 30-minute walk, skipping or working out to a DVD at home all count.

Exercise can help to relieve stress, making it the ideal antidote to tense moments during the day, which can otherwise leave you reaching for the ciggies.

Work out what your cigarette triggers are. If you reach for one when you pick up the phone, walk up and down the stairs instead while chatting. Or if you can, go outside and talk while you walk.

If your trigger is when you relax in front of the telly, stop watching and try skipping indoors or, again, go for a walk to distract you. Work out your own problem moments and plan ahead to avoid them by replacing them with something active.

Define your goals. If you don't have a specific goal, your training will lack direction.

To help support your goals, look for programmes that match your needs. For example, if you're running a race to raise money for charity, most charities provide training programmes.

Or, try one of the many fitness apps  Nike Training Club, for instance, is free to download.

Keep a training diary. Once you've worked out your training programme, it's important to keep a record of your workouts in a diary.

The easiest, quickest way to log details is to develop a code for the type and length of workout you do.

It also means you can add up your total number of exercise minutes each week. Aim to increase what you do until you have reached four to six hours a week.

Stop boredom creeping in. One of the biggest reasons we fall out of love with fitness is getting stuck in a rut.

Why not try inline skating or join a sports team? Aim to do at least two different types of cardiovascular exercise a week, whether it's running, cycling or swimming.

This keeps your body challenged and mind engaged.

Any activity that focuses your mind will ensure you use your body more effectively so you'll get better results.

Ideal activities include martial arts such as t'ai chi, karate, capoeira or yoga and Pilates.

Get a big exercise high. There's nothing like a high-intensity workout to give you an exercise high and get you wanting more.

Research shows intense bouts of exercise release more feelgood hormones and get you fitter quicker. Do at least one good stretch and relaxation session each week as well.
articles.teaser: NUTRITION and fitness experts tell you how to avoid piling on the pounds after you've quit smoking for good
articles.headline: Be a quitter and keep your figure
articles.subdeck: Stay fit and quit ... tips to giving up cigarettes while keeping trim

image.caption: Different perspective ... Renee Zellweger says that she feels lucky to have European parents

article.caption: Jerry Maguire actor's grown up to be a big star

articles.articlebody:
RENEE ZELLWEGER became a star thanks to her role opposite Tom Cruise in 1996 hit movie Jerry Maguire.

She is now established as one of the best-known and most highly paid actresses in Hollywood.

She won an Oscar for her role in the drama Cold Mountain and is famous for two films playing Bridget Jones.

Renee, 42, who had a short-lived marriage to singer Kenny Chesney in 2005, lives alone.

Here, she tells GARTH PEARCE about the influence her Norwegian-born mum Kjellfrid has had on her.

I DIDN'T grow up in a house where Mum focused on appearances. I don't remember her ever saying, "Wouldn't you be pretty if you did this or that?"

She never focused on anything beyond wanting me to be presentable  just well-groomed.

She wanted me to take care of myself and be healthy.

She did ask one or two questions when I became a cheerleader at high school because I would be teasing my hair and wearing lipstick and eyeliner.

I have an affiliation with a lot of countries. My mum was from Norway, my dad from Switzerland and my grandmother was Finnish, I have an Italian uncle, my first love was from South Africa and I was born in Texas.

I am definitely a Texan girl. It is a culture you really love in a Latin sort of way. You taste it and hear it and the climate is hot  Texas hot.

I felt lucky that my parents were European  different  and opened the doors to let me see America is not the centre of the universe.

It meant that, with Bridget Jones, I could go to London and enjoy all things English that make the country so wonderful.

During the making of the first film, I was even whistling songs by the Spice Girls.

But my mum was a realist about bringing up a teenage girl in America and kept a sense of humour.

She taught me that there are consequences for the things you say and do. She wanted me to grow up to be a good person. She and Dad liked simple and quiet. We had a very quiet house.

My mum didn't talk about her childhood growing up in Norway during the Second World War. Her sisters talked but all had difficulty in putting into words what they had seen.

They told about women giving birth in tunnels because there was no safe haven in any other structure.

And about being lost from family members and not being sure if they were alive.

So it was different for me, from my friends, growing up in a house where your mother was grateful just to have peace.

There was one thing which was never acceptable, though.

When I said: "I don't know how to do that", she would say: "Learn."

She encouraged me to get a college education (Renee has an English degree) as something to fall back on if acting didn't work out.

I moved to Los Angeles on December 6, 1993, to be exact.

My attitude was that I was going to see where it took me.

I had been working in Texas from the age of 21, and been in a couple of films. But I had pretty well exhausted my learning opportunities.

So I took a grungy little one-bed apartment and was scared to death of the future. It was a leap of faith, I guess.

I had some friends in LA who I had met on films but inside and emotionally, I felt alone.

To make a living, I worked in a bar called The Three Cubs on a street called Vine, behind the Mobil gas station.

It was an incredible place for a girl like me, who had lived in relatively safe places all her life.

There were crack deals being done on the street corners  so I would come back from the bar late at night then not be able to get out of my car to my apartment until the deals were completed.

I worked at the bar for two years. That was why Mum's guidance was so important and I stayed happy.

When you can take care of yourself and see your friends, that is all that matters.

The main difference that the film Jerry Maguire made in my life was I could pay my rent and didn't have to waitress any more. It gave me freedom.

I knew from the start that if I failed in acting, I always had my degree and could try a million things. I was not a "look at me" kind of girl.

I had gravitated toward acting because I had a vivid imagination and daydreamed a lot.

But I did not daydream about being on a film set, winning an Oscar or having people know my name.

I am grateful for the fact my mum never worried that I would compromise myself.

She was always telling me, 'You don't sit down enough'  but she learned to trust my instincts.
articles.teaser: ACTRESS Renee Zellweger reveals how her Norwegian mother influenced her career
articles.headline: Renee's European parents
articles.subdeck: Different perspective ... Renee Zellweger says that she feels lucky to have European parents

image.caption: Kelly Brook ... is the shape of a butternut squash

articles.articlebody:
ONE in five women are the shape of a BUTTERNUT SQUASH, reveals a new poll.

Kelly Brook and Mad Men beauty Christina Hendricks are examples. Their bust and hip sizes are the same but their waist is smaller by about 10in.

Experts also found one in four British women are carrot-shaped, 23 per cent are pears and 18 per cent are apples.

Big-hipped aubergines and busty broccolis scored less than six per cent each.

The survey, for the Vitality Show  from March 22 to 25 at London's Earls Court  studied 3,000 volunteers.

So are you a fruit or a vegetable? Use our guide.

SINGERS Jennifer Hudson and Kerry Katona are typical. Your waist is equal to or larger than your hips and bust. You only have 2-4 inches difference between all three.

ACTRESS Lindsay Lohan and TV presenter Ulrika Jonsson are broccoli-shaped.

Your bust is the widest part and your hips and waist are about the same size.

HOLLYWOOD A-listers Cameron Diaz and Nicole Kidman come under this category.

Your bust and hips are wider than your waist but only by about 6-8 inches.

THINK singer Jennifer Lopez or Sex And The City's Kristin Davis.

Your waist is at least 10in smaller than your hips. But your bust isn't as large as your hips.

CLAIRE RICHARDS from Steps and singer Adele are this shape.

Your bust is the smallest measurement and hips the largest. Your waist size lies between the two.
articles.teaser: ONE in five women are the shape of a BUTTERNUT SQUASH. So are you a fruit or a vegetable? Find out here
articles.headline: Why Kelly's a butternut squash
articles.subdeck: Kelly Brook ... is the shape of a butternut squash

image.caption: I thee fed ... couple

article.caption: Bloater to boater
End of the fat blue line
Man's waist measures more than his height
Slim boy 'fat'
I weighed more than my whole family

articles.articlebody:
A WOMAN who is trying to become the fattest in the world is getting married  to a CHEF.

Susanne Eman says her relationship with Parker Clack, 35, is "perfect".

She said: "We are a match made in heaven. I love eating and Parker loves cooking.

"He can help me reach my goal by feeding me."

Mum-of-two Susanne, 33, weighs about 54stone but hopes to reach more than 115stone to become the biggest person ever.

She said of her fiancé: "His cooking was part of the attraction. How could I resist a man with talents in the kitchen?

"His spaghetti bolognese is my favourite. I could eat it all day."

Parker, who lives with Susanne in Casa Grande, Arizona, calls himself a "Fat Admirer".

He said: "I support her, it makes her happy, and I love big women.

"I do worry about her health but eating puts a smile on her face."
articles.teaser: A WOMAN who is trying to reach 115 stone is getting married  to a FOODIE
articles.headline: 'Fat vow' Sue engaged to chef
articles.subdeck: I thee fed ... couple

image.caption: Slumperland ... girl recovers on a pavement of Britain's booze death capital

article.caption: Why we're all tee totally happy
Sunderland worst for alcohol deaths

articles.articlebody:
A YOUNG reveller lies slumped on the pavement in Sunderland  Britain's booze death capital.

Last week we revealed residents of the north-east city are more likely to drink themselves to death than in any other place in England and Wales.

In 2010 alone 36 people died there from alcohol-related illnesses.

Yet on Friday night The Sun saw 5pm to 5am pub crawls, girls as young as 16 downing cheap booze and a man in his 60s collapsed covered in blood.

One 23-year-old told us he'd rather DIE than stop drinking.

Britney Moore, 16, who was downing alcopops, said: "I'm not surprised by the statistics. We all like a drink here. There's nothing else to do on a night.

"I've got friends who have been going out since they were 14. It's easy to get your hands on drink at a young age."

Rachel Halliday, 27, added: "Last year someone was dying in the street and people walked past thinking he was drunk."
articles.teaser: SUNDERLAND residents ignore research they are more likely to drink selves to death
articles.headline: Sunder the influence...
articles.subdeck: Slumperland ... girl recovers on a pavement of Britain's booze death capital

article.caption: Two becomes one
Kate confesses: I miss Wills terribly
Kate is the Duchess of denim
It's the Royal blues as Queen has posh tea with Kate and Camilla

articles.articlebody:
CUT-price Kate is at it again  but this time the High Street style queen has been hitting the thrift shops.

Last week it was revealed the Duchess sent aides to a second-hand dress agency just a few miles from her Berkshire family home to find her outfits.

Her nearly new purchases from The Stock Exchange, in Sunninghill, include the grey Jesire coat dress she wore to a National Portrait Gallery event last month.

Described as a "premier venue for the fashion-conscious bargain hunter", the shop sells unwanted designer gear for clients and takes a 50 per cent cut of the sale price.

We sent Sun stylist Nana Acheampong to the shop to put together a wardrobe that was fit for a princess.

She found top High Streets labels including Kate's favourites LK Bennett and Karen Millen, plus fashion house labels including Chloe.

Nana, 25, said: "Staff revealed the store takes donations from a host of local TV presenters. They get a cut of any sales but anything not sold after five weeks goes to charity.

"They haven't seen the Duchess in the store but they were really excited when they saw Kate on TV wearing the Jesire dress.

"It looks like the Duchess has a secret shopper and The Stock Exchange are keen for whoever it is to continue shopping there."

Nana managed to put together four outfits for less than £180.

Here, Kate lookalike Chelsea Collins, 22, from Poole, Dorset, models our princess perfect looks.
articles.teaser: CUT-PRICE Kate is at it again  but this time the queen of high-street style has been hitting the thrift shops

image.caption: Risky business ... new warning highlights danger of unqualified beauty therapists

article.caption: I was terrified my PIP implants were a ticking timebomb. I just wanted them out
I spent £10,000 to look like one of my Barbies

articles.articlebody:
THOUSANDS of women are putting themselves at risk by inviting rogue beauty therapists into their homes.

Some agencies, such as online beauty therapist directory mobilebeauty.uk.com, allow anyone to register and advertise for work with NO checks.

Lauren Shalson, co-founder and director of reputable company Spa By Car, says: "Many online beauty agencies offer work or let therapists register based simply on a phone call. How can you safely send someone into a client's home without at least meeting them in person?

"After a thorough interview process, to be accepted on to our books our therapists need a minimum of NVQ level 2 and 3 and arrive in branded clothing, a branded car and bring proof of certificates to the appointment.

"We, as clients, need to be fully aware we could be letting anyone into our home and of the danger we could be placing ourselves in, especially if opting for a specialist treatment like intimate waxing. The mobile beauty sector is enjoying a surge because clients want therapies in the safety of their own home.

"Yet unscrupulous operators are sending unvetted, unqualified and uninsured therapists to clients' homes  exposing them to unimaginable risks. If you are using a mobile beauty therapist I would ask for references. If you are to use one at all I would use one that has been recommended to you and who has proved they can do a good job.

"I would ask who their insurance provider is and for proof of training  especially if you are going for eyelash extensions, where sharp tweezers are used which could cause a lot of damage in the hands of the wrong person. Be warned!"
articles.teaser: THOUSANDS of women are putting themselves at risk by inviting rogue beauty therapists into their homes
articles.headline: Truth about rogue beauticians...
articles.subdeck: Risky business ... new warning highlights danger of unqualified beauty therapists

image.caption: Au natural ... bushy brows are back

article.caption: Go with the glow
It's curl power for girls
Time for reflection
Think pink
How to get perfect pins
You nailed it

articles.articlebody:
THE statement brow is back. You can achieve luscious, full brows with a few make-up and grooming tricks even if you aren't blessed with the bushy variety.

The big brows sported by A-listers such as Megan Fox are going to be BIG business this year.

Caroline Frazer, Simple Skincare expert and celebrity make-up artist, says: "Fuller, bushier eyebrows are making a serious comeback for this spring and summer.

"Thicker brows frame the face and can take years off you as they are often associated with youth."

Caroline gave us her top tips to get the bushy look while still looking groomed.

She says: "Start by brushing your brows upwards so you can see where the hairs naturally lie and also check out the length.

"Always tweeze from underneath the brow and only ever pluck one hair at a time and in the direction of growth following the natural line.

"Don't pluck from above the brow. To finish the look or fill in any gaps, simply apply a brow pencil in gentle, feathering strokes and remember, less is more. Finish off with a slick of clear brow gel or if you have none to hand, a smear of clear lip balm."

Try Simple Kind To Lips Intensive Lip Moisturiser for £2.99 from supermarkets nationwide.

BROW TIDY: There's no need to worry if you've overplucked  superbrow serums are available to help encourage growth.

New RapidBrow serum (£37, Boots) claims to improve eyebrow density by up to 108 per cent in 60 days.

The High Street has also seen a huge surge in specialist brow bars such as Shavata (Harrods and House of Fraser nationwide) and Blink (Selfridges nationwide).

Their therapists are trained to get your brows back in order using various methods. The speedy services enable you to pop to the shops during your lunch break for a wow-brow transformation using techniques including waxing, plucking and threading.

Even men are opting for a quick brow tidy, with Blink brow bars reporting 20 per cent of their customers are male. Mark Wright is one of the two most requested looks.

NO NO BROWS: Although big is beautiful, the Scouse Brow, the dark pencilled-in monster arches, is a step too far for most of us.

The Scouse Brow is a dramatic example of a thick brow with a heavy, structured line that makes no attempt to appear soft or natural.

Avoid this heavy drawn-on one at all costs.

Big but NATURAL is the order of the day. So step away from your dark brown pencil. Instead, gently feather an eyeshadow that is two shades darker than your natural brow colour into your follicles with a tapered or slanted brush to help fill in any gaps and add definition.

We like Rimmel Professional Eyebrow Pencil for £2.99 from Boots.

HIGH DEFINITION BROW: The Saturday's Frankie Sandford and Una Healy are both fans of the HD Brows treatment, which uses a multi-step process to give you the perfect arch. These comprise tinting, waxing, threading, tweezing, soothing and finishing.

If you crave the regally perfect looks of the Duchess of Cambridge, HD may be the answer.

The high definition result means brows are so good they withstand scrutiny even in the most extreme close-up photo. It costs around £25 to £30. Or if you feel confident enough to do it yourself at home, try Benefit Brow Zings Brow Shaping Kit, £22.50, feelunique.com.

To soothe after plucking and keep brows slicked into shape, finish with Shavata After Care Gel, £5.95, Shavata.co.uk.
articles.teaser: CELEBRITY make-up artist Caroline Frazer shows us how to get statement eyebrows  without breaking the bank
articles.headline: Bow to force of the brow
articles.subdeck: Au natural ... bushy brows are back

image.caption: Clampdown ... Edward Bell in the dentist's chair

article.caption: Playing silly Buckers
Study says school run more stressful than work
Bish, gnash, bosh
Sugar risk of 'healthy' fruit drink
Could your mouth be telling you something?
Chew for 20 secs for crisps' 'salt burst'
Why a red plate helps weight loss

articles.articlebody:
ONE in four Brits now considers dental care a luxury rather than a necessity, according to new research.

A study carried out among 10,000 adults found that one in four has dodged the dentist's chair for 18 months, while one in nine has not been for more than five years.

Rising treatment costs have also led to four out of ten people claiming they simply cannot afford to have their teeth checked regularly.

The study also found that one in two parents admits they have taken their child to the dentist too late, with more than one in ten kids needing a filling before they were five.

The effects of poor dental hygiene extends beyond unsightly fillings.

Gum disease, which affects around 80 per cent of Brits at some point, has been linked to conditions ranging from heart disease to miscarriage and even erectile dysfunction.

Here, Professor Andrew Eder, clinical director at the London Tooth Wear Centre (restorative-dentistry.co.uk) and UCL Eastman Dental Institute, casts his expert eye over three people.

He tells MATTHEW BARBOUR what damage they have already done and what two of them can do to turn back the clock.

The third, Caroline Brill, has already had remedial treatment.

Edward Bell, 24

Tooth age 34



EDWARD is a musician from Islington, north London. He says:

As a child I spent a lot of time at boarding school, away from the prying eyes of my parents, so I didn't have anyone to stop me drinking gallons of lemonade and overdosing on sweets.

Even though we weren't supposed to have access to all the things you know are bad for your teeth at school, all the mums used to smuggle in treats which we would hide in our tuck boxes, so it felt like a bit of rebellious fun.

I've regularly drunk coffee from the age of nine, I smoked until about a year ago and I enjoy a glass of wine most evenings, and a few more at weekends, none of which can have helped.

When you're young, you don't really appreciate that you only get one set of adult teeth and never imagine that once you've done the damage, it can't easily be undone.

I also had an eight-year break from seeing a dentist from the age of 15 until about three months ago.

But it got to the point where I knew I had to get help  they weren't looking great and I was experiencing discomfort.

But three months ago, when I did finally bite the bullet and saw a dentist, she actually told me I wasn't anywhere near as bad as some other patients she had.

In the past few months I've had three fillings, upping my total to six, which isn't great for someone who's 24.

As a musician I had to opt for white fillings as my appearance is very important  and I'm now seeing the real cost of all those sweets and other bad habits.

And being a musician, my income stream is very erratic but once I hopefully have a steadier income I'm hoping to invest in some cosmetic dentistry.

When I went for my consultation with Professor Eder, he pointed out that I showed strong evidence of tooth grinding and worn-down enamel, which he said could be linked to a stressful life.

With all the costs and discomfort of bad teeth, I'm now really focused on my dental health.

I really do feel like I've turned a corner now and feel cautiously optimistic that I can at least stop the self-inflicted damage.

PROFESSOR EDER SAYS: "Edward fell from a skateboard as a child and caused some damage to his teeth.

"He has since experienced wear of his front teeth, and particularly his lower right canine, as a result of night grinding and clenching.

"Edward also had a high acidic intake from fizzy drinks as a teenager and also diluted fruit juices more recently, causing some loss of enamel on the biting surfaces of his back teeth, where some of the surface detail has been lost.

"With regard to managing this toothwear, Edward should limit acidic foods and drinks, use a daily fluoride mouthrinse and wear a very specific design of mouth guard over his upper teeth at night."

Dee Hutchings, 36

Tooth age 46



DEE, a charity worker from Battersea, south west London, lives with partner Hannah, 34. He says:

WHAT'S strange about my teeth is that I genuinely don't remember the tooth fairy visiting me on a regular basis as a child and certainly don't recall losing my teeth.

Most people would assume this would mean my teeth would be completely shot as your milk teeth are supposed to be weaker, added to the extra seven or so years of use they'd have had, but I don't have one filling!

I have the right number of teeth, so it doesn't feel or look that strange, although some at the front are small.

I guess I'm lucky in that growing up I always knew what to do to look after my teeth  I hardly ever had sweets or sugary, fizzy drinks.

And unlike other children who feel deprived as kids then abuse their teeth when they move away from home, I always knew why I wasn't allowed those tooth-rotting foods and drinks.

To this day I always water down acidic fruit juices. I brush two to three times a day and, like my whole family, know how important a generally healthy diet is.

Of course I have the same vices most adults do  I enjoy a glass of wine and love my coffee, and if I'm feeling particularly low-energy I might have a can of cola but it's definitely not a habit.

Where I think I might have fallen down in the past is that I haven't seen a dentist for several years now because of moving around and travelling.

I figured if I felt any pain or noticed any worrying changes, I'd book in to see one.

But having read all the stories about how hard it is to find a good NHS dentist, I was happy not to get something fixed until it broke.

When I saw Professor Eder, I was reassured that I don't have any cavities, although he did point out I have some tartar around the base of my teeth, which should be removed by a dental hygienist to protect my gums and teeth in the longer term.

One really interesting thing he picked up on was my front teeth showing signs of wear.

I confessed I suck a pen regularly at work  and I also push my tongue against my front teeth while I sleep.

Overall, I'm very happy with Professor Eder's verdict but looking at the close-up photos of my teeth, it's obvious how easily you can fool yourself into believing your teeth are great when in fact we could all take better care.

PROFESSOR EDER says: "As a result of sporting injuries when younger and tooth wear from night grinding  and also abrasion from holding a pen between his front teeth more recently  Dee's teeth are significantly older than his actual age.

"He should avoid holding a pen between his front teeth and could have some relatively straightforward cosmetic treatment.

"He should also wear a very specific design of mouth guard over his upper teeth at night."

Caroline Brill, 56

Tooth age 71



CAROLINE is a retired teacher from Mill Hill in north west London. She's married to Alan, 64, with two sons, Simon, 30, and David, 27.

She spent a five-figure sum on restorative dentistry and says:

Around 20 years ago I noticed my teeth disappearing  the front ones in particular had worn down to semi-circles and my gums would bleed whenever I bit into anything hard.

My dentist confirmed that my teeth were indeed disappearing and at Guy's Dental Hospital I was given the bad news that I'd need very costly restorative work to rebuild them.

As a teacher with two small children, I simply couldn't even contemplate the cost or the treatment time.

My dentist and the specialist I saw at Guy's suggested my problem could be that I wasn't producing enough saliva, which normally washes excess acid off the teeth.

Around three years ago my regular dentist referred me to Professor Eder.

Over the course of a year I saw him once or twice a week for three-hour sessions in which he completely rebuilt my teeth  first he replaced all of my many fillings.

I had to sleep wearing a large dental "splint" to widen my jaw enough to accept the new, larger crowns.

I then needed crown-lengthening surgery to cut back the gums and expose more of each tooth to provide an anchor for the new crowns. Each tooth was filed down before the new crowns were fitted.

That all finished in March 2010 and I couldn't be happier with the results.

I won't deny the whole process was very invasive and time-consuming  but I hardly suffered any pain.

My life has been transformed beyond measure  I can smile with confidence for the first time in years.

PROFESSOR EDER SAYS: "Caroline was referred by her dentist after years of problems with her teeth becoming increasingly short and restorations simply falling off her front teeth.

"Having been made aware of the erosion problems of acidic foods and drinks as well as attrition from grinding and clenching, Caroline opted for a comprehensive reconstruction."



myView



By PROFESSOR ANDREW EDER



TOOTH wear is the latest challenge to oral health. More than 50 per cent of children and pretty well all adults show signs of tooth surface loss.

From as young as we can remember, we are told to visit our dentist regularly and brush our teeth to stop them from becoming decayed and also to prevent gum problems.

As a positive result of these ingrained habits and also through the addition of fluoride to toothpaste and drinking water, we are keeping our teeth for longer.

However, wear and tear is instead becoming a really significant problem.

Tooth surface loss happens as a direct result of any of the following three causes.

First, many of us subconsciously grind our teeth, normally at night, often by way of stress relief  wearing away the enamel surface.

Second, abrasive foods in a "healthy" diet and over-brushing can cause teeth to simply wear away.

Third  and very much on the increase  is erosion of the outer tooth surfaces from acidic foods and drinks or even stomach acid regurgitation.

It is often hard to arrive at an absolute diagnosis and it is normally a combination of one or more of the above.

There are also many pressures seen in today's lifestyle. Prolonged periods of intentional vomiting are not only seen in the most unfortunate of anorexics and bulimics but also in those who simply wish to keep a trim figure for professional purposes such as acting or dancing.

An increasing problem is also seen in athletes, who regularly sip on sparkling sports drinks, and also regular swimmers, where the repeated contact with acidic chlorine-containing substances in the water can be a major problem.

Such sports-related issues will be more widely reported as we approach the Olympics.

Critical to success is identification of the cause of the tooth wear at the outset. Otherwise, the more comprehensive treatment is likely to fail.

For example, patients who present with regular stomach acid regurgitation may require medical investigation and management, while those drinking lots of fruit juice and sparkling drinks may simply be advised to reduce or modify their intake.

Social drug abuse is also highlighted as a cause of tooth wear as prolonged periods of grinding and clenching go hand-in-hand with the craving.

Patients may complain of sharp and sensitive teeth that can look shorter. Some may also report that chewing has become a bit of a problem.

It is the local dentist who plays a key role in the early diagnosis of such problems, together with dietary and social advice to help limit the problem from progressing irreversibly.
articles.teaser: WITH dental care now a luxury for a quarter of Brits, an expert rates 3 volunteers' tooth age and offers tips to improve teeth
articles.headline: Are your teeth ageing too soon?
articles.subdeck: Clampdown ... Edward Bell in the dentist's chair
